title: “A lifetime as a slave has prepared me for eternity as your master.”
body:
One of the coolest champion quotes that are above bios. It summarizes Xerath's backstory and personality in a single sentence.

"A new and terrible god" is also one of my favourites.

I think Riot handles Xerath really well describing wise, they really give the feel he is a terrifying oppenent and should be taken seriously. For that one of many reasons I just want more. More Shurima lore please. There are so much questions with so much plots about to happen.

Riot's the most "to be continued" faction is definitely Shurima, second is not even close IMO. This faction is literally screaming for "write me".

{{champion:163}} “As before, we will stand against you!”

****

Untold years ago, the Void invaded Runeterra.  It came from the heavens themselves onto the heights of Mount Targon, the darkness of the sky replaced with the darkness of its beings, whose eyes gleamed like the stars that once had shone.  All seemed lost.  But it was then that the Solari and Lunari, not yet riven by strife, charged forth from their halls and met the invaders together!

As legions of terrifying abominations emerged from glowing wounds in a landscape twisted into madness, the defenders strode forward, ranks closed and each aglow with Sun or Moon’s light.  They clashed against the looming darkness, Voidling limbs crashing against their shields and great blows of light battering the shade.  Dauntless, they drove their foe back up the Mountain and into the realm from whence they came.

We can still see evidence of that battle to this day.  Ancient carvings show Solarian and Lunarian figures standing together against incomprehensible creatures.  Though the Lunari have long ago been exterminated, the example of their forebears outlives them, and the Solari today would do well to heed it should the Void ever come back to Mount Targon.

****

Taliyah hopped off her rock, crossed her arms, and spun about, rising on a column of stone amid the busiest market square in all Shurima.  The sound of churning rock turned the heads of hagglers and merchants alike, who stopped and stared at the stone-weaving girl.

“Hear this!” she cried, “Monsters from between worlds have come to this one.  They mean to _end_ it.”

Eyes in the crowd grew wide, and she raised her voice further, “They can hunt any one tribe, defeat any one army, and overrun any one city.  If left alone, they will kill everyone, destroy everything, and turn into _more_ monsters whatever stands in their path.”

Children clutches their parents’ hands as Taliyah continued, “They have already taken Mount Targon; in just a few months, they will be pounding on the gates of this very city.”

Spreading her arms and regarding one fearful face after another, Taliyah said, “Nomads, Targonians, Shurimans, we must unite.  If we are to live, then every tribe, every army, and every city must come together as one.”

“Legends say that our ancestors faced these monsters—these creatures of the Void—once before.” Taliyah said, the faintest hints of a smile spreading across her face, “The Solari and Lunari joined forces and stopped them at Mount Targon.”

“They lived opposite lives.  They worshipped opposite things.  One day, indeed, they fought until one was wiped out.  But on that day,” said she, raising a finger, “as darkness loomed, the Sun and Moon together cast their light to drive it back!”

“So, as these Voidlings now loom over us,” Taliyah asked, “as before, will you stand against them?”
